text:
its nice to know that julia still works fine if you're very exuberant about your return value
```julia> foo(x) = return return x+1
foo (generic function with 1 method)
julia> foo(3)
4```

elements.text: its nice to know that julia still works fine if you're very exuberant about your return value

julia> foo(x) = return return x+1
foo (generic function with 1 method)
julia> foo(3)
4

text: one of Julia's great design decisions is to make basically everything an expression.

elements.text: one of Julia's great design decisions is to make basically everything an expression.

text:
It can be surprising though:
```julia> function foo(x)
           return 5 & return 1
       end
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> foo(3)
1

julia> function bar(x)
           return false || return true
       end
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> bar(3)
true```

elements.text:
julia> function foo(x)
           return 5 & return 1
       end
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> foo(3)
1

julia> function bar(x)
           return false || return true
       end
foo (generic function with 1 method)

julia> bar(3)
true

text: What’s going on in this example, is it trying to evaluate return (5 & return 1) and therefore ends up evaluating return 1 and exiting right there?

elements.text: What’s going on in this example, is it trying to evaluate return (5 & return 1) and therefore ends up evaluating return 1 and exiting right there?
